SENT.plain: The prognosis of adults with Burkitt's lymphoma is very poor and depends on initial CNS and/or bone marrow involvement
We report results in nine adult patients with CNS (n = 9) and/or bone marrow involvement (n = 7) treated in first complete remission (CR) with allogeneic bone marrow transplantation (BMT)
CNS treatment before the conditioning regimen consisted of cranial irradiation at 15 Gy (n = 8) and intrathecal chemotherapy (n = 9)
The conditioning regimen included cyclophosphamide and total body irradiation (TBI) in a single dose
No postgraft CNS prophylaxis was administered
At the present time, seven patients are alive and disease-free at 18, 23, 44, 47, 54, 54, and 59 months
Two patients died at 14 and 7 months from transfusion-related acquired immune deficiency syndrome and bacterial septicemia and were disease-free at the time of their death
These preliminary results should encourage the use of BMT
A prospective randomized trial is warranted to further specify and investigate the advantages of allogeneic BMT versus conventional chemotherapy
